question: What type of display system does the F-35 use to show target and threat information?
generated_answer: The F-35 uses a panoramic cockpit display, a large 20 by 8-inch piece of glass, to show target and threat information. This display is part of the Tactical Situation Display (TSD) where the output from the fusion engine is presented. The display can be manipulated through the touchscreen, cursor hooking, or voice control. It provides a big picture view of the battlespace and correlates and fuses all information from onboard sensors and offboard datalinks. The F-35 also features an all-glass instrument panel with a 10 x 20-inch flat-panel screen for displaying target and threat information overlaid on a moving map. This system is part of the integrated mission systems designed for the F-35. Additionally, the F-35 utilizes the Distributed Aperture System (DAS), which integrates six cooled, staring mid-wave infrared sensors for full-time spherical coverage of the tactical environment. DAS outputs are processed by the Lockheed Martin Integrated Core Processor (ICP) and generate target symbology on the F-35 panoramic cockpit display. Furthermore, the F-35's helmet-mounted display system (HMDS) provides pilots with an unobstructed view of the outside world, allowing them to see through the aircraft and track threats. In summary, the F-35 employs a combination of a panoramic cockpit display, integrated mission systems, the Distributed Aperture System, and a helmet-mounted display system to show target and threat information.
